data.title: The Faculty for Chemistry and Pharmacy
data.meta_description: Faculty for Chemistry and Pharmacy Ludwig-Maximilians-UniversitÃ¤t MÃ¼nchen
data.text:
Our faculty is located on the Campus GroÃhadern/Martinsried in Munich's GroÃhadern district. It has a rich history and has stood for excellent research and teaching for several hundred years. In our three departments biochemistry, chemistry and pharmacy we conduct research into many relevant questions of the present and aim to make our contribution for a better society and future.

In teaching, we have always taken new, forward-looking paths. Recently, this has included the establishment of contemporary and needs-oriented new courses of study such as "Pharmaceutical Sciences" the international, English-language Master's in Biochemistry and the Bachelor's and Master's in Chemistry.

In addition to the many publications in excellent international journals and numerous innovative patents of our research groups, our research successes include the founding of the Cluster of Excellence "Center for Integrated Protein Science Munich (CIPSM), the Graduate School of Excellence âQuantitative Biosciences Munichâ (QBM), the Cluster of Excellence âE-Conversionâ (e-conversion, together with the Technical University of Munich), the future cluster âCluster for Nucleic Acid Therapeutics Munichâ (CNATM) and other Collaborative Research Centers. In addition to our numerous programs in basic research, biotechnology companies are also involved in order to make the Munich region a globally visible melting pot for innovation, progress and teaching in the field of life sciences.

The faculty was a pioneer in establishing the tenure-track system to appoint young researchers to a professorship directly after their post-doctoral period and thus compete with the Anglo-Saxon system for the best talent. In addition, the faculty was one of the first in Germany to proactively initiate appointments in order to bring outstanding researchers from the USA back to Germany.

Members of the faculty have also received many internationally acclaimed awards. For example, six faculty members have been awarded prizes in the Leibniz Program of the German Research Foundation (DFG). Around 30 faculty members have received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) to date. In addition to other programs, the DFG-funded Collaborative Research Centres have kept the third-party funding ratio high.

Every year, the RÃ¶mer Foundation honors the best graduates and researchers in the Departments of Chemistry and Biochemistry at a graduation ceremony.

Two-part steel sculpture by James Reineking. The circular piazza in Lucca from the 18th century, which is surrounded by houses and was created on the site of an ancient, formerly oval amphitheater, served as his starting point.

Building A - Gene Center

Â© Jan Greune

Building A - Gene Center

Yoshiyuki Miura: "Vibrations of Space" in the entrance hall of House C (90.000 EUR). A spherical triangle is formed from a multitude of stone pillars made of black African granite (total weight approx. 500 kg) according to a precisely calculated system.

Julia Mangold: Steel sculpture in the entrance hall of House D (31.565 EUR). The block lying on the floor with a diagonal of 6x2 m length functions as a central resting point and as a meeting place.

Julia Mangold: Stele and three-color mural in the entrance hall House E (9.416 EUR). The sculpture builds a bridge to the one in House D.

Afra Dopfer: Wall relief in the entrance hall of House F (78.110 EUR). Her sculptures adapt to the given architecture with mathematical precision and are not easily recognizable as such at first glance. On the two 8 m high walls, the imprint of an imaginary sphere with a diameter of 50 m is realized in an extremely flat work.

Statue of Baeyer

The circular spatial sculpture "Ring" by the brothers Maik and Dirk LÃ¼bbert cuts through the air space between the two foyers and continues in the flooring of the cafeteria and the upper foyer. The interrupted granite ring is 60 cm wide with a diameter of 11 m.

Artists' collective Viola Relle and Raphael Weilguni: "Archaeology of the Future" - Artwork in front of ICEM and BioSys
